Macro.heading: CPI
Macro.summary: On September 1, 2025, the US headline CPI rose by 0.25% to a level of 324.8, with the core CPI increasing similarly by 0.25% to 330.8. Food prices showed a somewhat larger rise of 0.64%, while shelter costs advanced more modestly by 0.17%. This reading reflects a modest acceleration in inflation compared to recent trends, indicating a slightly firmer price environment.

Macro.heading: PPI
Macro.summary: On 2025-09-01, the US Producer Price Index (PPI) for final demand rose to 149.779, marking a 0.31% increase from the prior reading of 149.316. This gain was driven primarily by a slight increase in goods prices (up 0.07%), while services prices edged down marginally by 0.02%. The overall PPI rise indicates modest upward pressure on producer prices, reflecting a slightly hotter inflationary trend compared to the relatively stable or easing readings observed in recent months.

Macro.heading: Employment
Macro.summary: On September 1, 2025, US payrolls increased modestly by 0.07% to 159,626, while the unemployment rate rose to 4.4% from 4.3%. This suggests a slight cooling in labor market conditions compared to previous readings, indicating a marginal easing after a period of tightness.

Macro.heading: Bank Reserves
Macro.summary: As of November 26, 2025, US bank reserves stood at approximately 2.90 million, marking a modest increase of 0.27% from the prior week. This slight rise suggests a subtle loosening in liquidity conditions compared to recent periods, reflecting a stable but mildly more accommodative banking reserve environment.

Macro.heading: Consumer Sentiment
Macro.summary: On November 1, 2025, US Consumer Sentiment fell to 51, down 4.85% from 53.6 in October. This decline marks a moderate cooling compared to recent months, indicating a slight weakening in consumer confidence.

Macro.heading: Inflation Expectations
Macro.summary: On November 1, 2025, US inflation expectations declined, with the one-year measure falling to 4.5% from 4.6% the previous month (-2.17%) and the five-year measure dropping more sharply to 3.4% from 3.9% (-12.82%). This marks a notable easing in inflation expectations compared to recent readings, suggesting a moderation in anticipated price pressures over both the short and medium term.

Macro.heading: Gamma Regime (VIX9D / VIX / VIX3M)
Macro.summary: On 2025-11-28, the Gamma Regime, measured by the ratio of near-term to longer-term VIX indices, remained positive with the VIX9D at 13.61, below the VIX at 16.35 and well under the VIX3M at 19.64. This configuration indicates a relatively stable short-term volatility environment compared to recent history, reflecting a moderately easing volatility regime.

Macro.heading: FOMC
Macro.title: Federal Reserve issues FOMC statement
Macro.summary:
The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) announced a 25 basis point reduction in the target range for the federal funds rate to 3.75–4.00 percent, signaling a pause in the rate cut cycle as the Committee decided to end reductions in aggregate securities holdings by December 1. This adjustment reflects the FOMC’s assessment that economic activity continues to expand at a moderate pace, though job gains have slowed and unemployment has slightly risen but remains low. Inflation has increased since early in the year and remains somewhat elevated, maintaining pressure on the Committee’s dual mandate of maximum employment and 2 percent inflation.

Forward guidance emphasized the Committee’s attentiveness to elevated uncertainty and balanced risks in the economic outlook, noting a recent rise in downside risks to employment. The FOMC remains committed to supporting maximum employment and returning inflation to its 2 percent target, and indicated readiness to adjust monetary policy as necessary based on incoming data across labor markets, inflation dynamics, financial conditions, and global developments. The Committee’s communication stressed careful monitoring of the evolving outlook before further policy moves.

The policy decision was not unanimous. Ten members, including Chair Powell and Vice Chair Williams, supported the 25 basis point cut. Two dissents were recorded: Stephen I. Miran preferred a more aggressive 50 basis point reduction, while Jeffrey R. Schmid advocated for no change in the target rate at this meeting. This vote split underscores differing views on the appropriate pace and scale of policy easing amidst ongoing economic uncertainty.
